text.title: part2_BDSM as business: An interview with the owners of a dungeon

p: Rebecca: We're still looking out for their needs. They're still human beings, and they have needs. So each and every person, I look out for their needs. And they all think I'm their best friend.
head: Their home life

p.hi: DS: What do your kids feel about this as a business?

p: Bill: They don't know.
Rebecca: They don't know. That's why we want to be anonymous.
Bill: I don't know, but I don't think it'd be healthy.
Rebecca: I think my almost-seventeen-year-old would be okay with it. My middle one I don't think would be very happy, and my youngest would probably want to do it.

p.hi: DS: What do they think you do?

p: Bill: They know I'm a psychologist.

p.hi: DS: Do you have a practice?

p: Bill: I haven't for a long time. They know I have some other businesses as well; we run some other businesses.

p.hi: DS: Kids just donâ€™t care what their parents do.

p: Rebecca: Right. Exactly. But in a way, I feel like I'm mothering 30 girls sometimes.

p.hi: DS: Is that taxing on you?

p: Rebecca: It's exhausting.
Bill: That's why people can't do this business.

p.hi: DS: How do you handle that?

p: Rebecca: Sometimes, some days I go home and cry.

p.hi: DS: So when people bring problems into work, which happens in any workplace, you're the one that they probably turn to.

p: Rebecca: Yeah.

p.hi: DS: Do either of you think ever of leaving this business?

p: Bill: Yeah, we will.
Rebecca: We will at some point.
Bill: I'll retire and live off my millions.
Rebecca: At this point, I--we've worked so hard. I mean, at the beginning, I didn't think I'd actually be proud of it. Now it's something--

Bill: We have a lot of people that depend on us here. A lot of girls we put through grad school, a lot of girls. We've lent money to a lot of people here; we've helped out a lot of people--we've done that.
Rebecca: It's so much part of who I am, and I would never believe that it was actually me. I would never have thought this would be part of who I am, and at this point it is.

p.hi: DS: But your kids know you work nights. What do you tell them when you're leaving?

p: Rebecca: I just try to tell them--I try to condense my work so that I can be home with them also.

p.hi: DS: But what do they think that you're doing?

p: Rebecca: Work.
Rebecca: I am doing work.
Bill: A non-issue. I have an advertising business as well, a little advertising business.
